headline.main: From Iceland, With Vigor: 'LazyTown' Hits Chelsea

docs.abstract: Magnus Sheving, 41, creator and star of Nickelodeon children's show LazyTown, appears in person at Chelsea Piers, Manhattan; comments, in interview, on getting children physically motivated; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Magnus Scheving has a message for the children who watch his television show, ''LazyTown,'' that is evident in every quick swish of his arms, every one-handed push-up, every high kick and backflip. But just in case that message was not completely obvious, he put it into words at a live appearance before 500 young (and not so young) fans at the Chelsea Piers on Thursday morning.
docs.snippet: Magnus Scheving, who hosts a show on Nickelodeon, wants to encourage children to be physically active and to eat healthy foods - by watching television.

headline.main: Alchemy for the Dinner Table; Science's Quest for Tasty, Fat-Free, Life-Preserving Additives

docs.abstract: Every major food producer and food-ingredient company has ordered it2
docs.lead_paragraph: Low-fat fried chicken may seem like a contradiction in terms, but not to Stephen Kelleher. On a recent summer morning, he hovered over a whirling assembly line as a waterfall of gray liquid cascaded over slabs of breaded chicken. Then the magic began. During the bath in the liquid solution, which consisted of water and protein molecules extracted from a slurry of chicken or fish tissue, a thin, imperceptible shield formed around the meat. When the chicken was submerged in oil, the coating blocked fat from being absorbed from the fryer. Voilà! The chicken contained 50 percent less fat than a typical piece of fried chicken.
docs.snippet: With two-thirds of Americans overweight, food companies have commissioned their scientists to develop healthier products.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Food companies have assigned their scientists to develop healthier products. In the case of Alpha Bits, "letter integrity" issues were a challenge.

multimedia.caption: A Quest to Banish Fat
multimedia.credit: Food companies have assigned their scientists to develop healthier products. In the case of Alpha Bits, "letter integrity" issues were a challenge.

headline.main: Preventive Care Found Lacking in the Overweight

docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity is a well-established cause of health problems. But some problems may occur needlessly, suggests a new study that found that overweight people were given preventive medical care less often than other people. The researchers, whose report appears in the September issue of The American Journal of Public Health, found significant differences in how often obese women were given mammograms and Pap smears to screen for cancer. Obese men and women were also less likely to receive flu shots.
docs.snippet: A new study found that overweight people were given preventive medical care less often than other people.
